Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Story: The end-of-shift whistle echoed across the site, and I grabbed my broom, ready to sweep up the dust and debris from my section. My foreman always reminded us: “A clean site is a safe site.” I knew if I left even a stray nail, someone could get hurt, and I’d be the one to blame. As I started sweeping, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was 7:00 p.m.—the time I always called my parents. Mom would be waiting, probably already sitting by the phone, eager to hear about my day. I could picture Dad, too, asking if I was eating well, if I was safe. They worried if I missed even one call. But the site was a mess tonight, and the foreman was watching. If I left now, I’d let my crew down and risk a warning. If I waited, I’d break my promise to my parents. My hands tightened on the broom as I stared at my phone, torn between the two worlds that needed me.
